Award.AbstractNarration:
The AAAI Doctoral Consortium (DC) brings together established researchers and mid-career Ph.D. students for a two-day workshop where students and faculty interact in a range of settings to provide both formal and informal career and research mentoring. As a means of encouraging young and upcoming researchers in Artificial Intelligence, the AAAI Doctoral Consortium has been proven to be a relatively inexpensive and extremely effective model. Many of the current reviewers, mentors, organizers, and panelists were once student participants in prior AAAI DCs.

The Intellectual Merit of the AAAI Doctoral Consortium lies in the unique opportunity for junior researchers to gain high quality feedback on academic and social issues relevant to their career, from senior researchers within their community. As part of the DC program, mentors and students interact in meetings, panels, working lunches, and during oral presentations and discussions. For many students, this is the only opportunity to receive focused input from researchers other than members of their dissertation committee at their home institution. Students not only gain the experience of giving a talk on their thesis research and receiving specific feedback on their work, they also are given the opportunity to discuss more personal issues, such as balancing work and family when pursuing a research career after completion of their Ph.D. studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Consortium is a two-day, intensive symposium that pairs mid-career Ph.D. students (primarily from the U.S., but also international students) with prominent, senior members of the research community for focused mentoring. The goals of the Consortium are to: 1) provide a forum for up-and-coming researchers to share their dissertation research with the AAAI community; 2) enable a diverse audience of AAAI conference attendees to interact with supported students in a variety of formal and informal settings; and 3) give participants ample feedback and direction on their dissertation work to help guide them toward successful completion of their degree and towards increasing their contributions to the AAAI community. 


The DC provides a number of opportunities for training and professional development. The 2016 DC included 17 students, 14 of which came from U.S. institutions and 12 of which were supported by NSF funds. During and prior to the DC, students:

  • were paired with a senior member of their community. Students shared a two-page abstract of their dissertation, along with a draft of their presentation slides. Mentors and students met to discuss the slides and summary prior to the students' scheduled presentations. were allotted 40 minutes in the schedule for their presentation and discussion of their work. Of the 40 minutes, 20 were dedicated to their presentation and 20 were dedicated to a group discussion and feedback on their dissertation and presentation. The discussion was led by the mentors. had numerous opportunities for informal conversations with senior community members and peers during coffee breaks, working lunches, and a dinner event. presented their work to the larger AAAI audience at a poster session. 

The AAAI DC is a unique avenue for developing up-and-coming research talent in the AI community. As far as we know there are no other venues that provide as deep and meaningful interaction among Ph.D. students and senior community members---the mentoring opportunity is unparalleled in the AI community. 17 students had the opportunity to participate in 2016. Three of the participants summed it up very nicely in their feedback:

  • "Almost everything was fantastic! The feedback sessions for both the presenter and the audience were great, constructive, and thoughtful. My mentor was awesome (Mak). I totally want to stay in touch with him and recommend him as a future mentor. Having lunch together and the evening dinner was great as well."
  • "The feedback from the mentors was by far the best part about the doctoral consortium. I'm in a department where not many people are experts in my field, so having the resources of the DC was extremely useful. The connections made were also useful. I still am in contact with my mentor and some of the students in the DC."
  • "Overall, I liked everything about the DC.  It was great to see more overview research talks from all the student participants (in comparison to the brief and specific research talks at conferences) - it allowed me to better understand the goals and research challenges of other fields of AI.  The feedback and connections with other professors was also great and extremely helpful.  I am keeping in touch with many of the people I met at the DC both for the remainder of AAAI and after the conference."
